Our business is heavily concentrated in consumer lending, which carries a high risk of loss that is different from and typically higher than the risk of loss associated with commercial lending.
Our business is particularly sensitive to macroeconomic conditions affecting the US economy, consumer spending and consumer credit.
Inflation has had and could continue to have an adverse effect on consumer spending.
A rising interest rate environment impacts our profitability.
COVID-19 has resulted in widespread volatility and deterioration in employment levels and business conditions.
We adjusted payment policies and created a program to support borrowers, allowing deferrals for up to 180 days.
The lingering effects of COVID-19 have not allowed effective recovery for our medallion loans.
The ultimate effects of COVID-19 on loan portfolios and consumer businesses are uncertain, risking substantial losses.
Higher gasoline prices, inflation, unstable real estate values impact credit quality and consumer demand.
Our balance sheet consists of a significant percentage of non-prime consumer loans associated with higher delinquency rates.
Delinquencies, defaults, and losses on loans could worsen during an economic downturn.

elements.title: Risk Factors Related to Demand and Loan Financing

data.value: Our business, financial condition, and results of operations could be negatively impacted if we are unsuccessful in developing and maintaining relationships with dealerships, contractors, and FSPs.
A large proportion of our new loan originations are concentrated in our top ten relationships, which could negatively affect demand for our products.
There is significant competition for the contractor and FSP relationships we depend on.

data.key: Impact of demographic and economic factors
data.value: Demand for products may be reduced due to various factors such as demographic patterns or macroeconomic conditions.

Commercial borrowers may prepay loans, which could adversely impact our net interest income and return on equity.
While we may hedge against interest rate fluctuations, adverse developments from these activities could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition.

elements.title: Loan Collateral in Process of Foreclosure Movement (2021-2022)

data.value: This table shows the movement of loan collateral in foreclosure process from December 2021 to December 2022, broken down by Recreation and Medallion categories. The total foreclosure amount decreased from $37,430,000 to $21,819,000 over the year, primarily due to cash payments received ($12,289,000), sales ($10,375,000), and collateral valuation adjustments ($5,738,000). The Medallion category saw a more significant reduction compared to the Recreation category.

elements.title: Loan collateral in process of foreclosure

data.value: This table shows the movement of loan collateral in process of foreclosure from December 2020 to December 2021. The total collateral value decreased from $54,560,000 to $37,430,000, primarily due to cash payments received ($14,173,000), sales ($9,879,000), and valuation adjustments ($8,966,000). The table tracks both recreation and medallion loans, with medallion loans representing the majority of the portfolio. The medallion portion decreased significantly from $53,128,000 to $35,710,000 over the period.

This table shows a financial schedule of deposits and borrowings from 2023 to 2027 and thereafter, with historical data from December 2021 and 2022. The total deposits and borrowings are expected to decrease from $513,218,000 in 2023 to $203,595,000 in 2027. Deposits form the largest component, with interest rates varying from 1.91% for deposits to 7.66% for retail notes. The total portfolio had a weighted average interest rate of 2.43%. The total obligations decreased from $1,832,184,000 in December 2022 to $1,477,251,000 in December 2021.

This table shows the breakdown of deposits by maturity period. The majority of deposits (approximately 68.4%) are held for over one year, amounting to 1,101,454. Short-term deposits (three months or less) account for 152,517, while medium-term deposits between three months and one year total 355,701. The total deposits across all time periods sum to 1,609,672.
